content: The study of techniques for creating works of art, art history, and how to critique art.
The study of the art form whose medium is sound and silence.
The study of theatre arts, such as acting, and design and technical theatre.
The study of the art form consisting of purposefull sequence of human movement.
The study of how to make a film.
The study of argument and persuasion.
The study of how to motivate and organize a group of people to achieve a common goal.
The study of how to perform a presentation to a live audience in a structured and deliberate manner.
The study of how to create a yearbook. Encompasses jornalism, layout, design, and management.
The study of how to gather, process, and disseminate new and information.
The study of how to read, write, speak, listen, and use language effectively in a variety of content areas.
The ability to read text, process it and understand its meaning.
A focus on reading nonfiction: biographies, autobiographies, books about history, social studies, science, and the arts,  and technical texts.
A focus on reading fiction: poems, novels, short stories and dramas.
Understanding and working knowledge of concepts of print, the alphabetic principle, and other basic conventions of the English writing system.
The study of language use, from vocabulary and syntax to the development and organization of ideas
The study of how to participate in collaborative discussions, summarize and analyze oral arguments, and present knowledge and ideas.
The study of grammar and vocabulary.
The study of the past, particularly how it relates to humans.
The study of the people inhabiting the European continenet, from roughly 1200 BC to the present.
The study of US history, typically from 1491 to the present.
The study of history from a global perspective.
The study of the history of a particular state.
The study of latin, a classical language originally spoken in Italy.
The study of spanish, a romance language that originated in Spain.
The study of german, a west germanic language.
The study of french, a romance language descending from Latin.
The study of standard chinese, a form of Mandarin that originated in Beijing.
The study of quantity, structure, space, and change.
The study of what a number is and how units can be used to solve problems.
The study of mathematical symbols and rules for manipulating these symbols.
The study of the relation between inputs and outputs, where one input determines one output.
Links classroom mathematics and statistics to everyday life, work, and decision-making.
A branch of mathematics concerned with questions of shape, size, relative position of figures, and the properties of space.
The study of the collection, analysis, interpretation, presentation, and organization of data. And the analysis of random phenomena.
The study of human sexuality.
The study of how to write using a pen or pencil.
The study of how to write using a keyboard.
Encourages psychomotor learning through play and movement exploration to promote health.
Career based education.
The study of how to increase performance on standardized tests.
The study of science content, the scientific method, and social science.
A branch of science that studies non-living systems.
The study of the composition, structure, and change of matter.
The study of matter and its motion through space and time.
The study of all fields of science dealing with the Earth.
The study of stars, galaxies, planets, moon, asteroids, comets, and nebulae.
A branch of science that studies living organisms.
The study of life and living organsisms, including their structure, function, growth, evolution, distribution, and taxonomy.
An applied science, that studies diagnosing, treating, and preventing disease.
A branch of science that studies the application of scientific knowledge.
The application of scientific, economic, social and practical knowledge in order to invent, design, build, maintain, and research.
The study of the interdependence of science and technology.
The scientific and practical approach to computation and its applications.
A discipline that deals with systems of geovernment and they anlysis of politics.
The study of the theoretical and practical aspects of citizenship, rights and duties.
The study of lands, the features, the inhabitants, and the phenomena of Earth.
A discipline that seeks to describe the factors which determin production, distribution, and consumption of goods and services.

Partition circles and rectangles into two and four equal shares, describe the shares using the words halves, fourths, and quarters, and use the phrases half of, fourth of, and quarter of. Describe the whole as two of, or four of the shares. Understand for these examples that decomposing into more equal shares creates smaller shares.
meta: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

content: Compose two-dimensional shapes (rectangles, squares, trapezoids, triangles, half-circles, and quarter-circles) or three-dimensional shapes (cubes, right rectangular prisms, right circular cones, and right circular cylinders) to create a composite shape, and compose new shapes from the composite shape.
meta: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

content: Distinguish between defining attributes (e.g., triangles are closed and three-sided) versus non-defining attributes (e.g., color, orientation, overall size); build and draw shapes to possess defining attributes.
meta: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

content: Organize, represent, and interpret data with up to three categories; ask and answer questions about the total number of data points, how many in each category, and how many more or less are in one category than in another.
Tell and write time in hours and half-hours using analog and digital clocks.

Express the length of an object as a whole number of length units, by laying multiple copies of a shorter object (the length unit) end to end; understand that the length measurement of an object is the number of same-size length units that span it with no gaps or overlaps.
meta: Measure lengths indirectly and by iterating length units.

content: Order three objects by length; compare the lengths of two objects indirectly by using a third object.
meta: Measure lengths indirectly and by iterating length units.

content: Subtract multiples of 10 in the range 10-90 from multiples of 10 in the range 10-90 (positive or zero differences), using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used.
meta: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Given a two-digit number, mentally find 10 more or 10 less than the number, without having to count; explain the reasoning used.
meta: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Add within 100, including adding a two-digit number and a one-digit number, and adding a two-digit number and a multiple of 10, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used. Understand that in adding two-digit numbers, one adds tens and tens, ones and ones; and sometimes it is necessary to compose a ten.
meta: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Compare two two-digit numbers based on meanings of the tens and ones digits, recording the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, and <.
meta: Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Understand that the two digits of a two-digit number represent amounts of tens and ones. Understand the following as special cases:
meta: Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Count to 120, starting at any number less than 120. In this range, read and write numerals and represent a number of objects with a written numeral.
meta: Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Determine the unknown whole number in an addition or subtraction equation relating three whole numbers.
meta: Work with addition and subtraction equations.

content: Understand the meaning of the equal sign, and determine if equations involving addition and subtraction are true or false.
meta: Work with addition and subtraction equations.

content: Add and subtract within 20, demonstrating fluency for addition and subtraction within 10. Use strategies such as counting on; making ten (e.g., 8 + 6 = 8 + 2 + 4 = 10 + 4 = 14); decomposing a number leading to a ten (e.g., 13 - 4 = 13 - 3 - 1 = 10 - 1 = 9); using the relationship between addition and subtraction (e.g., knowing that 8 + 4 = 12, one knows 12 - 8 = 4); and creating equivalent but easier or known sums (e.g., adding 6 + 7 by creating the known equivalent 6 + 6 + 1 = 12 + 1 = 13).
Relate counting to addition and subtraction (e.g., by counting on 2 to add 2).
Understand subtraction as an unknown-addend problem.
meta: Understand and apply properties of operations and the relationship between addition and subtraction.

content: Apply properties of operations as strategies to add and subtract.
meta: Understand and apply properties of operations and the relationship between addition and subtraction.

content: Solve word problems that call for addition of three whole numbers whose sum is less than or equal to 20, e.g., by using objects, drawings, and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
meta: Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction.

content: Use addition and subtraction within 20 to solve word problems involving situations of adding to, taking from, putting together, taking apart, and comparing, with unknowns in all positions, e.g., by using objects, drawings, and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
meta: Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction.

content: The numbers 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90 refer to one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, or nine tens (and 0 ones).
meta: Understand that the two digits of a two-digit number represent amounts of tens and ones. Understand the following as special cases:
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: The numbers from 11 to 19 are composed of a ten and one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, or nine ones.
meta: Understand that the two digits of a two-digit number represent amounts of tens and ones. Understand the following as special cases:
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: 10 can be thought of as a bundle of ten ones — called a "ten."
meta: Understand that the two digits of a two-digit number represent amounts of tens and ones. Understand the following as special cases:
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Partition circles and rectangles into two, three, or four equal shares, describe the shares using the words halves, thirds, half of, a third of, etc., and describe the whole as two halves, three thirds, four fourths. Recognize that equal shares of identical wholes need not have the same shape.
meta: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

content: Partition a rectangle into rows and columns of same-size squares and count to find the total number of them.
meta: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

content: Recognize and draw shapes having specified attributes, such as a given number of angles or a given number of equal faces. Identify triangles, quadrilaterals, pentagons, hexagons, and cubes.
meta: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

content: Draw a picture graph and a bar graph (with single-unit scale) to represent a data set with up to four categories. Solve simple put-together, take-apart, and compare problems using information presented in a bar graph.

Generate measurement data by measuring lengths of several objects to the nearest whole unit, or by making repeated measurements of the same object. Show the measurements by making a line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked off in whole-number units.
Solve word problems involving dollar bills, quarters, dimes, nickels, and pennies, using $ and ¢ symbols appropriately.
Tell and write time from analog and digital clocks to the nearest five minutes, using a.m. and p.m. Know relationships of time (e.g., minutes in an hour, days in a month, weeks in a year).

Represent whole numbers as lengths from 0 on a number line diagram with equally spaced points corresponding to the numbers 0, 1, 2, …, and represent whole-number sums and differences within 100 on a number line diagram.
meta: Relate addition and subtraction to length.

content: Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve word problems involving lengths that are given in the same units, e.g., by using drawings (such as drawings of rulers) and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
meta: Relate addition and subtraction to length.

content: Measure to determine how much longer one object is than another, expressing the length difference in terms of a standard length unit.
meta: Measure and estimate lengths in standard units.

content: Estimate lengths using units of inches, feet, centimeters, and meters.
meta: Measure and estimate lengths in standard units.

content: Measure the length of an object twice, using length units of different lengths for the two measurements; describe how the two measurements relate to the size of the unit chosen.
meta: Measure and estimate lengths in standard units.

content: Measure the length of an object by selecting and using appropriate tools such as rulers, yardsticks, meter sticks, and measuring tapes.
meta: Measure and estimate lengths in standard units.

content: Explain why addition and subtraction strategies work, using place value and the properties of operations.
meta: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Mentally add 10 or 100 to a given number 100—900, and mentally subtract 10 or 100 from a given number 100—900.
meta: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Use estimation strategies to make reasonable estimates in problem solving.
meta: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Add and subtract within 1000, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method. Understand that in adding or subtracting three-digit numbers, one adds or subtracts hundreds and hundreds, tens and tens, ones and ones; and sometimes it is necessary to compose or decompose tens or hundreds.
meta: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Add up to four two-digit numbers using strategies based on place value and properties of operations.
meta: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Fluently add and subtract within 100 using strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction.
meta: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Compare two three-digit numbers based on meanings of the hundreds, tens, and ones digits, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.
meta: Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Read and write numbers to 1000 using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form.
meta: Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Count within 1000; skip-count by 2s, 5s, 10s, and 100s.
meta: Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Understand that the three digits of a three-digit number represent amounts of hundreds, tens, and ones; e.g., 706 equals 7 hundreds, 0 tens, and 6 ones. Understand the following as special cases:
meta: Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Use addition to find the total number of objects arranged in rectangular arrays with up to 5 rows and up to 5 columns; write an equation to express the total as a sum of equal addends.
meta: Work with equal groups of objects to gain foundations for multiplication.

content: Determine whether a group of objects (up to 20) has an odd or even number of members, e.g., by pairing objects or counting them by 2s; write an equation to express an even number as a sum of two equal addends.
meta: Work with equal groups of objects to gain foundations for multiplication.

content: Fluently add and subtract within 20 using mental strategies. By end of Grade 2, know from memory all sums of two one-digit numbers.

Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve one- and two-step word problems involving situations of adding to, taking from, putting together, taking apart, and comparing, with unknowns in all positions, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
meta: Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction.

content: The numbers 100, 200, 300, 400, 500, 600, 700, 800, 900 refer to one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, or nine hundreds (and 0 tens and 0 ones).
meta: Understand that the three digits of a three-digit number represent amounts of hundreds, tens, and ones; e.g., 706 equals 7 hundreds, 0 tens, and 6 ones. Understand the following as special cases:
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: 100 can be thought of as a bundle of ten tens — called a "hundred."
meta: Understand that the three digits of a three-digit number represent amounts of hundreds, tens, and ones; e.g., 706 equals 7 hundreds, 0 tens, and 6 ones. Understand the following as special cases:
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Explain equivalence of fractions in special cases, and compare fractions by reasoning about their size.
meta: Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.

content: Understand a fraction as a number on the number line; represent fractions on a number line diagram.
meta: Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.

content: Understand a fraction 1/b as the quantity formed by 1 part when a whole is partitioned into b equal parts; understand a fraction a/b as the quantity formed by a parts of size 1/b.
meta: Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.

content: Partition shapes into parts with equal areas. Express the area of each part as a unit fraction of the whole.
meta: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

content: Understand that shapes in different categories (e.g., rhombuses, rectangles, and others) may share attributes (e.g., having four sides), and that the shared attributes can define a larger category (e.g., quadrilaterals). Recognize rhombuses, rectangles, and squares as examples of quadrilaterals, and draw examples of quadrilaterals that do not belong to any of these subcategories.
meta: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

content: Solve real world and mathematical problems involving perimeters of polygons, including finding the perimeter given the side lengths, finding an unknown side length, and exhibiting rectangles with the same perimeter and different areas or with the same area and different perimeters.
meta: Geometric measurement: recognize perimeter as an attribute of plane figures and distinguish between linear and area measures.

content: Relate area to the operations of multiplication and addition.
meta: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

content: Measure areas by counting unit squares (square cm, square m, square in, square ft, and improvised units).
meta: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

content: Recognize area as an attribute of plane figures and understand concepts of area measurement.
meta: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

content: Generate measurement data by measuring lengths using rulers marked with halves and fourths of an inch. Show the data by making a line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked off in appropriate units— whole numbers, halves, or quarters.

Draw a scaled picture graph and a scaled bar graph to represent a data set with several categories. Solve one- and two-step "how many more" and "how many less" problems using information presented in scaled bar graphs.

Measure and estimate liquid volumes and masses of objects using standard units of grams (g), kilograms (kg), and liters (l). Add, subtract, multiply, or divide to solve one-step word problems involving masses or volumes that are given in the same units, e.g., by using drawings (such as a beaker with a measurement scale) to represent the problem.
meta: Solve problems involving measurement and estimation of intervals of time, liquid volumes, and masses of objects.

content: Tell and write time to the nearest minute and measure time intervals in minutes. Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of time intervals in minutes, e.g., by representing the problem on a number line diagram.
meta: Solve problems involving measurement and estimation of intervals of time, liquid volumes, and masses of objects.

content: Multiply one-digit whole numbers by multiples of 10 in the range 10—90 (e.g., 9 × 80, 5 × 60) using strategies based on place value and properties of operations.
meta: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Fluently add and subtract within 1000 using strategies and algorithms based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction.
meta: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Use place value understanding to round whole numbers to the nearest 10 or 100.
meta: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Identify arithmetic patterns (including patterns in the addition table or multiplication table), and explain them using properties of operations.
meta: Solve problems involving the four operations, and identify and explain patterns in arithmetic.

content: Solve two-step word problems using the four operations. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding.
meta: Solve problems involving the four operations, and identify and explain patterns in arithmetic.

content: Fluently multiply and divide within 100, using strategies such as the relationship between multiplication and division (e.g., knowing that 8 × 5 = 40, one knows 40 ÷ 5 = 8) or properties of operations. By the end of Grade 3, know from memory all products of two one-digit numbers.
Understand division as an unknown-factor problem.
meta: Understand properties of multiplication and the relationship between multiplication and division.

content: Apply properties of operations as strategies to multiply and divide.
meta: Understand properties of multiplication and the relationship between multiplication and division.

content: Determine the unknown whole number in a multiplication or division equation relating three whole numbers.
meta: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and division.

content: Use multiplication and division within 100 to solve word problems in situations involving equal groups, arrays, and measurement quantities, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
meta: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and division.

content: Interpret whole-number quotients of whole numbers, e.g., interpret 56 ÷ 8 as the number of objects in each share when 56 objects are partitioned equally into 8 shares, or as a number of shares when 56 objects are partitioned into equal shares of 8 objects each.
meta: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and division.

content: Interpret products of whole numbers, e.g., interpret 5 × 7 as the total number of objects in 5 groups of 7 objects each.
meta: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and division.

content: Compare two fractions with the same numerator or the same denominator by reasoning about their size. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.
meta: Explain equivalence of fractions in special cases, and compare fractions by reasoning about their size.
Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.

content: Express whole numbers as fractions, and recognize fractions that are equivalent to whole numbers.
meta: Explain equivalence of fractions in special cases, and compare fractions by reasoning about their size.
Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.

content: Recognize and generate simple equivalent fractions, e.g., 1/2 = 2/4, 4/6 = 2/3). Explain why the fractions are equivalent, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.
meta: Explain equivalence of fractions in special cases, and compare fractions by reasoning about their size.
Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.

content: Understand two fractions as equivalent (equal) if they are the same size, or the same point on a number line.
meta: Explain equivalence of fractions in special cases, and compare fractions by reasoning about their size.
Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.

content: Represent a fraction a/b on a number line diagram by marking off a lengths 1/b from 0. Recognize that the resulting interval has size a/b and that its endpoint locates the number a/b on the number line.
meta: Understand a fraction as a number on the number line; represent fractions on a number line diagram.
Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.

content: Represent a fraction 1/b on a number line diagram by defining the interval from 0 to 1 as the whole and partitioning it into b equal parts. Recognize that each part has size 1/b and that the endpoint of the part based at 0 locates the number 1/b on the number line.
meta: Understand a fraction as a number on the number line; represent fractions on a number line diagram.
Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.

content: Recognize area as additive. Find areas of rectilinear figures by decomposing them into non-overlapping rectangles and adding the areas of the non-overlapping parts, applying this technique to solve real world problems.
meta: Relate area to the operations of multiplication and addition.
Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

content: Use tiling to show in a concrete case that the area of a rectangle with whole-number side lengths a and b + c is the sum of a × b and a × c. Use area models to represent the distributive property in mathematical reasoning.
meta: Relate area to the operations of multiplication and addition.
Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

content: Multiply side lengths to find areas of rectangles with whole-number side lengths in the context of solving real world and mathematical problems, and represent whole-number products as rectangular areas in mathematical reasoning.
meta: Relate area to the operations of multiplication and addition.
Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

content: Find the area of a rectangle with whole-number side lengths by tiling it, and show that the area is the same as would be found by multiplying the side lengths.
meta: Relate area to the operations of multiplication and addition.
Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

content: A plane figure which can be covered without gaps or overlaps by n unit squares is said to have an area of n square units.
meta: Recognize area as an attribute of plane figures and understand concepts of area measurement.
Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

content: A square with side length 1 unit, called "a unit square," is said to have "one square unit" of area, and can be used to measure area.
meta: Recognize area as an attribute of plane figures and understand concepts of area measurement.
Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

content: Compare two decimals to hundredths by reasoning about their size. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two decimals refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by using the number line or another visual model.
meta: Understand decimal notation for fractions, and compare decimal fractions.

content: Use decimal notation for fractions with denominators 10 or 100.
meta: Understand decimal notation for fractions, and compare decimal fractions.

content: Express a fraction with denominator 10 as an equivalent fraction with denominator 100, and use this technique to add two fractions with respective denominators 10 and 100.
meta: Understand decimal notation for fractions, and compare decimal fractions.

content: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication to multiply a fraction by a whole number.
meta: Build fractions from unit fractions by applying and extending previous understandings of operations on whole numbers.

content: Understand a fraction a/b with a > 1 as a sum of fractions 1/b.
meta: Build fractions from unit fractions by applying and extending previous understandings of operations on whole numbers.

content: Compare two fractions with different numerators and different denominators, e.g., by creating common denominators or numerators, or by comparing to a benchmark fraction such as 1/2. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.
meta: Extend understanding of fraction equivalence and ordering.

content: Explain why a fraction a/b is equivalent to a fraction (n × a)/(n × b) by using visual fraction models, with attention to how the number and size of the parts differ even though the two fractions themselves are the same size. Use this principle to recognize and generate equivalent fractions.
meta: Extend understanding of fraction equivalence and ordering.

content: Recognize a line of symmetry for a two-dimensional figure as a line across the figure such that the figure can be folded along the line into matching parts. Identify line-symmetric figures and draw lines of symmetry.
meta: Draw and identify lines and angles, and classify shapes by properties of their lines and angles.

content: Classify two-dimensional figures based on the presence or absence of parallel or perpendicular lines, or the presence or absence of angles of a specified size. Recognize right triangles as a category, and identify right triangles. (Two-dimensional shapes should include special triangles, e.g., equilateral, isosceles, scalene, and special quadrilaterals, e.g., rhombus, square, rectangle, parallelogram, trapezoid.)
meta: Draw and identify lines and angles, and classify shapes by properties of their lines and angles.

content: Draw points, lines, line segments, rays, angles (right, acute, obtuse), and perpendicular and parallel lines. Identify these in two-dimensional figures.
meta: Draw and identify lines and angles, and classify shapes by properties of their lines and angles.

content: Recognize angle measure as additive. When an angle is decomposed into non-overlapping parts, the angle measure of the whole is the sum of the angle measures of the parts. Solve addition and subtraction problems to find unknown angles on a diagram in real world and mathematical problems, e.g., by using an equation with a symbol for the unknown angle measure.
meta: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of angle and measure angles.

content: Measure angles in whole-number degrees using a protractor. Sketch angles of specified measure.
meta: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of angle and measure angles.

content: Recognize angles as geometric shapes that are formed wherever two rays share a common endpoint, and understand concepts of angle measurement:
meta: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of angle and measure angles.

content: Make a line plot to display a data set of measurements in fractions of a unit (1/2, 1/4, 1/8). Solve problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions by using information presented in line plots.
Apply the area and perimeter formulas for rectangles in real world and mathematical problems.
meta: Solve problems involving measurement and conversion of measurements from a larger unit to a smaller unit.

content: Use the four operations to solve word problems involving distances, intervals of time, liquid volumes, masses of objects, and money, including problems involving simple fractions or decimals, and problems that require expressing measurements given in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit. Represent measurement quantities using diagrams such as number line diagrams that feature a measurement scale.
meta: Solve problems involving measurement and conversion of measurements from a larger unit to a smaller unit.

content: Know relative sizes of measurement units within one system of units including km, m, cm; kg, g; lb, oz.; l, ml; hr, min, sec. Within a single system of measurement, express measurements in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit. Record measurement equivalents in a two column table.
meta: Solve problems involving measurement and conversion of measurements from a larger unit to a smaller unit.

content: Find whole-number quotients and remainders with up to four-digit dividends and one-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.
meta: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-digit numbers, using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.
meta: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Fluently add and subtract multi-digit whole numbers using the standard algorithm.
meta: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Use place value understanding to round multi-digit whole numbers to any place.
meta: Generalize place value understanding for multi-digit whole numbers.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Read and write multi-digit whole numbers using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form. Compare two multi-digit numbers based on meanings of the digits in each place, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.
meta: Generalize place value understanding for multi-digit whole numbers.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Recognize that in a multi-digit whole number, a digit in one place represents ten times what it represents in the place to its right.
meta: Generalize place value understanding for multi-digit whole numbers.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Generate a number or shape pattern that follows a given rule. Identify apparent features of the pattern that were not explicit in the rule itself.

Find all factor pairs for a whole number in the range 1—100. Recognize that a whole number is a multiple of each of its factors. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1—100 is a multiple of a given one-digit number. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1—100 is prime or composite.
meta: Gain familiarity with factors and multiples.

content: Solve multistep word problems posed with whole numbers and having whole-number answers using the four operations, including problems in which remainders must be interpreted. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding.
meta: Use the four operations with whole numbers to solve problems.

content: Multiply or divide to solve word problems involving multiplicative comparison, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem, distinguishing multiplicative comparison from additive comparison.
meta: Use the four operations with whole numbers to solve problems.

content: Interpret a multiplication equation as a comparison, e.g., interpret 35 = 5 × 7 as a statement that 35 is 5 times as many as 7 and 7 times as many as 5. Represent verbal statements of multiplicative comparisons as multiplication equations.
meta: Use the four operations with whole numbers to solve problems.

content: Solve word problems involving multiplication of a fraction by a whole number, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication to multiply a fraction by a whole number.
Build fractions from unit fractions by applying and extending previous understandings of operations on whole numbers.

content: Understand a multiple of a/b as a multiple of 1/b, and use this understanding to multiply a fraction by a whole number.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication to multiply a fraction by a whole number.
Build fractions from unit fractions by applying and extending previous understandings of operations on whole numbers.

content: Understand a fraction a/b as a multiple of 1/b.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication to multiply a fraction by a whole number.
Build fractions from unit fractions by applying and extending previous understandings of operations on whole numbers.

content: Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions referring to the same whole and having like denominators, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.
meta: Understand a fraction a/b with a > 1 as a sum of fractions 1/b.
Build fractions from unit fractions by applying and extending previous understandings of operations on whole numbers.

content: Add and subtract mixed numbers with like denominators, e.g., by replacing each mixed number with an equivalent fraction, and/or by using properties of operations and the relationship between addition and subtraction.
meta: Understand a fraction a/b with a > 1 as a sum of fractions 1/b.
Build fractions from unit fractions by applying and extending previous understandings of operations on whole numbers.

content: Decompose a fraction into a sum of fractions with the same denominator in more than one way, recording each decomposition by an equation. Justify decompositions, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.
meta: Understand a fraction a/b with a > 1 as a sum of fractions 1/b.
Build fractions from unit fractions by applying and extending previous understandings of operations on whole numbers.

content: Understand addition and subtraction of fractions as joining and separating parts referring to the same whole.
meta: Understand a fraction a/b with a > 1 as a sum of fractions 1/b.
Build fractions from unit fractions by applying and extending previous understandings of operations on whole numbers.

content: An angle that turns through n one-degree angles is said to have an angle measure of n degrees.
meta: Recognize angles as geometric shapes that are formed wherever two rays share a common endpoint, and understand concepts of angle measurement:
Geometric measurement: understand concepts of angle and measure angles.

content: An angle is measured with reference to a circle with its center at the common endpoint of the rays, by considering the fraction of the circular arc between the points where the two rays intersect the circle. An angle that turns through 1/360 of a circle is called a "one-degree angle," and can be used to measure angles.
meta: Recognize angles as geometric shapes that are formed wherever two rays share a common endpoint, and understand concepts of angle measurement:
Geometric measurement: understand concepts of angle and measure angles.

content: Apply and extend previous understandings of division to divide unit fractions by whole numbers and whole numbers by unit fractions.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division to multiply and divide fractions.

content: Solve real world problems involving multiplication of fractions and mixed numbers, e.g., by using visual fraction models or equations to represent the problem.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division to multiply and divide fractions.

content: Interpret multiplication as scaling (resizing), by:
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division to multiply and divide fractions.

content: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication to multiply a fraction or whole number by a fraction.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division to multiply and divide fractions.

content: Interpret a fraction as division of the numerator by the denominator (a/b = a ÷ b). Solve word problems involving division of whole numbers leading to answers in the form of fractions or mixed numbers, e.g., by using visual fraction models or equations to represent the problem.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division to multiply and divide fractions.

content: Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions referring to the same whole, including cases of unlike denominators, e.g., by using visual fraction models or equations to represent the problem. Use benchmark fractions and number sense of fractions to estimate mentally and assess the reasonableness of answers.
meta: Use equivalent fractions as a strategy to add and subtract fractions.

content: Add and subtract fractions with unlike denominators (including mixed numbers) by replacing given fractions with equivalent fractions in such a way as to produce an equivalent sum or difference of fractions with like denominators.
meta: Use equivalent fractions as a strategy to add and subtract fractions.

content: Classify two-dimensional figures in a hierarchy based on properties.
meta: Classify two-dimensional figures into categories based on their properties.

content: Understand that attributes belonging to a category of two-dimensional figures also belong to all subcategories of that category.
meta: Classify two-dimensional figures into categories based on their properties.

content: Represent real world and mathematical problems by graphing points in the first quadrant of the coordinate plane, and interpret coordinate values of points in the context of the situation.
meta: Graph points on the coordinate plane to solve real-world and mathematical problems.

content: Use a pair of perpendicular number lines, called axes, to define a coordinate system, with the intersection of the lines (the origin) arranged to coincide with the 0 on each line and a given point in the plane located by using an ordered pair of numbers, called its coordinates. Understand that the first number indicates how far to travel from the origin in the direction of one axis, and the second number indicates how far to travel in the direction of the second axis, with the convention that the names of the two axes and the coordinates correspond (e.g., x-axis and x-coordinate, y-axis and y-coordinate).
meta: Graph points on the coordinate plane to solve real-world and mathematical problems.

content: Relate volume to the operations of multiplication and addition and solve real world and mathematical problems involving volume.
meta: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of volume and relate volume to multiplication and to addition.

content: Measure volumes by counting unit cubes, using cubic cm, cubic in, cubic ft, and improvised units.
meta: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of volume and relate volume to multiplication and to addition.

content: Recognize volume as an attribute of solid figures and understand concepts of volume measurement.
meta: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of volume and relate volume to multiplication and to addition.

content: Make a line plot to display a data set of measurements in fractions of a unit (1/2, 1/4, 1/8). Use operations on fractions for this grade to solve problems involving information presented in line plots.
Convert among different-sized standard measurement units within a given measurement system (e.g., convert 5 cm to 0.05 m), and use these conversions in solving multi-step, real world problems.
meta: Convert like measurement units within a given measurement system.

content: Add, subtract, multiply, and divide decimals to hundredths, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used.
meta: Perform operations with multi-digit whole numbers and with decimals to hundredths.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Find whole-number quotients of whole numbers with up to four-digit dividends and two-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.
meta: Perform operations with multi-digit whole numbers and with decimals to hundredths.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Fluently multiply multi-digit whole numbers using the standard algorithm.
meta: Perform operations with multi-digit whole numbers and with decimals to hundredths.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Use place value understanding to round decimals to any place.
meta: Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Read, write, and compare decimals to thousandths.
meta: Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Explain patterns in the number of zeros of the product when multiplying a number by powers of 10, and explain patterns in the placement of the decimal point when a decimal is multiplied or divided by a power of 10. Use whole-number exponents to denote powers of 10.
meta: Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Recognize that in a multi-digit number, a digit in one place represents 10 times as much as it represents in the place to its right and 1/10 of what it represents in the place to its left.
meta: Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Generate two numerical patterns using two given rules. Identify apparent relationships between corresponding terms. Form ordered pairs consisting of corresponding terms from the two patterns, and graph the ordered pairs on a coordinate plane.
Express a whole number in the range 2–50 as a product of its prime factors. For example, find the prime factors of 24 and express 24 as 2 × 2 × 2 × 3.
Write simple expressions that record calculations with numbers, and interpret numerical expressions without evaluating them.
Use parentheses, brackets, or braces in numerical expressions, and evaluate expressions with these symbols.

Solve real world problems involving division of unit fractions by non-zero whole numbers and division of whole numbers by unit fractions, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of division to divide unit fractions by whole numbers and whole numbers by unit fractions.
Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division to multiply and divide fractions.

content: Interpret division of a whole number by a unit fraction, and compute such quotients.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of division to divide unit fractions by whole numbers and whole numbers by unit fractions.
Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division to multiply and divide fractions.

content: Interpret division of a unit fraction by a non-zero whole number, and compute such quotients.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of division to divide unit fractions by whole numbers and whole numbers by unit fractions.
Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division to multiply and divide fractions.

content: Explaining why multiplying a given number by a fraction greater than 1 results in a product greater than the given number (recognizing multiplication by whole numbers greater than 1 as a familiar case); explaining why multiplying a given number by a fraction less than 1 results in a product smaller than the given number; and relating the principle of fraction equivalence a/b = (n×a)/(n×b) to the effect of multiplying a/b by 1.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division to multiply and divide fractions.

content: Comparing the size of a product to the size of one factor on the basis of the size of the other factor, without performing the indicated multiplication.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division to multiply and divide fractions.

content: Find the area of a rectangle with fractional side lengths by tiling it with unit squares of the appropriate unit fraction side lengths, and show that the area is the same as would be found by multiplying the side lengths. Multiply fractional side lengths to find areas of rectangles, and represent fraction products as rectangular areas.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication to multiply a fraction or whole number by a fraction.
Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division to multiply and divide fractions.

content: Interpret the product (a/b) × q as a parts of a partition of q into b equal parts; equivalently, as the result of a sequence of operations a × q ÷ b.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication to multiply a fraction or whole number by a fraction.
Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division to multiply and divide fractions.

content: Recognize volume as additive. Find volumes of solid figures composed of two non-overlapping right rectangular prisms by adding the volumes of the non-overlapping parts, applying this technique to solve real world problems.
meta: Relate volume to the operations of multiplication and addition and solve real world and mathematical problems involving volume.
Geometric measurement: understand concepts of volume and relate volume to multiplication and to addition.

content: Apply the formulas V = l × w × h and V = b × h for rectangular prisms to find volumes of right rectangular prisms with whole-number edge lengths in the context of solving real world and mathematical problems.
meta: Relate volume to the operations of multiplication and addition and solve real world and mathematical problems involving volume.
Geometric measurement: understand concepts of volume and relate volume to multiplication and to addition.

content: Find the volume of a right rectangular prism with whole-number side lengths by packing it with unit cubes, and show that the volume is the same as would be found by multiplying the edge lengths, equivalently by multiplying the height by the area of the base. Represent threefold whole-number products as volumes, e.g., to represent the associative property of multiplication.
meta: Relate volume to the operations of multiplication and addition and solve real world and mathematical problems involving volume.
Geometric measurement: understand concepts of volume and relate volume to multiplication and to addition.

content: A solid figure which can be packed without gaps or overlaps using n unit cubes is said to have a volume of n cubic units.
meta: Recognize volume as an attribute of solid figures and understand concepts of volume measurement.
Geometric measurement: understand concepts of volume and relate volume to multiplication and to addition.

content: A cube with side length 1 unit, called a "unit cube," is said to have "one cubic unit" of volume, and can be used to measure volume.
meta: Recognize volume as an attribute of solid figures and understand concepts of volume measurement.
Geometric measurement: understand concepts of volume and relate volume to multiplication and to addition.

content: Compare two decimals to thousandths based on meanings of the digits in each place, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.
meta: Read, write, and compare decimals to thousandths.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Read and write decimals to thousandths using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form, e.g., 347.392 = 3 × 100 + 4 × 10 + 7 × 1 + 3 × (1/10) + 9 × (1/100) + 2 × (1/1000).
meta: Read, write, and compare decimals to thousandths.
Number and Operations in Base Ten

content: Summarize numerical data sets in relation to their context, such as by:
Display numerical data in plots on a number line, including dot plots, histograms, and box plots.
Recognize that a measure of center for a numerical data set summarizes all of its values with a single number, while a measure of variation describes how its values vary with a single number.
Understand that a set of data collected to answer a statistical question has a distribution which can be described by its center, spread, and overall shape.
Recognize a statistical question as one that anticipates variability in the data related to the question and accounts for it in the answers.

Use variables to represent two quantities in a real-world problem that change in relationship to one another; write an equation to express one quantity, thought of as the dependent variable, in terms of the other quantity, thought of as the independent variable. Analyze the relationship between the dependent and independent variables using graphs and tables, and relate these to the equation.
meta: Represent and analyze quantitative relationships between dependent and independent variables.

content: Write an inequality of the form x > c or x < c to represent a constraint or condition in a real-world or mathematical problem. Recognize that inequalities of the form x > c or x < c have infinitely many solutions; represent solutions of such inequalities on number line diagrams.
meta: Reason about and solve one-variable equations and inequalities.

content: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by writing and solving equations of the form x + p = q and px = q for cases in which p, q and x are all nonnegative rational numbers.
meta: Reason about and solve one-variable equations and inequalities.

content: Use variables to represent numbers and write expressions when solving a real-world or mathematical problem; understand that a variable can represent an unknown number, or, depending on the purpose at hand, any number in a specified set.
meta: Reason about and solve one-variable equations and inequalities.

content: Understand solving an equation or inequality as a process of answering a question: which values from a specified set, if any, make the equation or inequality true? Use substitution to determine whether a given number in a specified set makes an equation or inequality true.
meta: Reason about and solve one-variable equations and inequalities.

content: Identify when two expressions are equivalent (i.e., when the two expressions name the same number regardless of which value is substituted into them).
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of arithmetic to algebraic expressions.

content: Apply the properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of arithmetic to algebraic expressions.

content: Write, read, and evaluate expressions in which letters stand for numbers.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of arithmetic to algebraic expressions.

content: Write and evaluate numerical expressions involving whole-number exponents.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of arithmetic to algebraic expressions.

content: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by graphing points in all four quadrants of the coordinate plane. Include use of coordinates and absolute value to find distances between points with the same first coordinate or the same second coordinate.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.

content: Understand ordering and absolute value of rational numbers.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.

content: Understand a rational number as a point on the number line. Extend number line diagrams and coordinate axes familiar from previous grades to represent points on the line and in the plane with negative number coordinates.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.

content: Understand that positive and negative numbers are used together to describe quantities having opposite directions or values (e.g., temperature above/below zero, elevation above/below sea level, credits/debits, positive/negative electric charge); use positive and negative numbers to represent quantities in real-world contexts, explaining the meaning of 0 in each situation.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.

content: Find the greatest common factor of two whole numbers less than or equal to 100 and the least common multiple of two whole numbers less than or equal to 12. Use the distributive property to express a sum of two whole numbers 1—100 with a common factor as a multiple of a sum of two whole numbers with no common factor.
meta: Compute fluently with multi-digit numbers and find common factors and multiples.

content: Fluently add, subtract, multiply, and divide multi-digit decimals using the standard algorithm for each operation.
meta: Compute fluently with multi-digit numbers and find common factors and multiples.

content: Fluently divide multi-digit numbers using the standard algorithm.
meta: Compute fluently with multi-digit numbers and find common factors and multiples.

content: Interpret and compute quotients of fractions, and solve word problems involving division of fractions by fractions, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division to divide fractions by fractions.

content: Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.
meta: Understand ratio concepts and use ratio reasoning to solve problems.

content: Understand the concept of a unit rate a/b associated with a ratio a:b with b ≠ 0, and use rate language in the context of a ratio relationship.
meta: Understand ratio concepts and use ratio reasoning to solve problems.

content: Understand the concept of a ratio and use ratio language to describe a ratio relationship between two quantities.
meta: Understand ratio concepts and use ratio reasoning to solve problems.

content: Represent three-dimensional figures using nets made up of rectangles and triangles, and use the nets to find the surface area of these figures. Apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
meta: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, surface area, and volume.

content: Draw polygons in the coordinate plane given coordinates for the vertices; use coordinates to find the length of a side joining points with the same first coordinate or the same second coordinate. Apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
meta: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, surface area, and volume.

content: Find the volume of a right rectangular prism with fractional edge lengths by packing it with unit cubes of the appropriate unit fraction edge lengths, and show that the volume is the same as would be found by multiplying the edge lengths of the prism. Apply the formulas V = l w h and V = b h to find volumes of right rectangular prisms with fractional edge lengths in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
meta: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, surface area, and volume.

content: Find the area of right triangles, other triangles, special quadrilaterals, and polygons by composing into rectangles or decomposing into triangles and other shapes; apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
meta: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, surface area, and volume.

content: Relating the choice of measures of center and variability to the shape of the data distribution and the context in which the data were gathered.
meta: Summarize numerical data sets in relation to their context, such as by:

content: Giving quantitative measures of center (median and/or mean) and variability (interquartile range and/or mean absolute deviation), as well as describing any overall pattern and any striking deviations from the overall pattern with reference to the context in which the data were gathered.
meta: Summarize numerical data sets in relation to their context, such as by:

content: Describing the nature of the attribute under investigation, including how it was measured and its units of measurement.
meta: Summarize numerical data sets in relation to their context, such as by:

content: Reporting the number of observations.
meta: Summarize numerical data sets in relation to their context, such as by:

content: Evaluate expressions at specific values of their variables. Include expressions that arise from formulas used in real-world problems. Perform arithmetic operations, including those involving whole-number exponents, in the conventional order when there are no parentheses to specify a particular order (Order of Operations).
meta: Write, read, and evaluate expressions in which letters stand for numbers.
Apply and extend previous understandings of arithmetic to algebraic expressions.

content: Identify parts of an expression using mathematical terms (sum, term, product, factor, quotient, coefficient); view one or more parts of an expression as a single entity.
meta: Write, read, and evaluate expressions in which letters stand for numbers.
Apply and extend previous understandings of arithmetic to algebraic expressions.

content: Write expressions that record operations with numbers and with letters standing for numbers.
meta: Write, read, and evaluate expressions in which letters stand for numbers.
Apply and extend previous understandings of arithmetic to algebraic expressions.

content: Distinguish comparisons of absolute value from statements about order.
meta: Understand ordering and absolute value of rational numbers.
Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.

content: Understand the absolute value of a rational number as its distance from 0 on the number line; interpret absolute value as magnitude for a positive or negative quantity in a real-world situation.
meta: Understand ordering and absolute value of rational numbers.
Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.

content: Write, interpret, and explain statements of order for rational numbers in real-world contexts.
meta: Understand ordering and absolute value of rational numbers.
Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.

content: Interpret statements of inequality as statements about the relative position of two numbers on a number line diagram.
meta: Understand ordering and absolute value of rational numbers.
Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.

content: Find and position integers and other rational numbers on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram; find and position pairs of integers and other rational numbers on a coordinate plane.
meta: Understand a rational number as a point on the number line. Extend number line diagrams and coordinate axes familiar from previous grades to represent points on the line and in the plane with negative number coordinates.
Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.

content: Understand signs of numbers in ordered pairs as indicating locations in quadrants of the coordinate plane; recognize that when two ordered pairs differ only by signs, the locations of the points are related by reflections across one or both axes.
meta: Understand a rational number as a point on the number line. Extend number line diagrams and coordinate axes familiar from previous grades to represent points on the line and in the plane with negative number coordinates.
Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.

content: Recognize opposite signs of numbers as indicating locations on opposite sides of 0 on the number line; recognize that the opposite of the opposite of a number is the number itself, e.g., -(-3) = 3, and that 0 is its own opposite.
meta: Understand a rational number as a point on the number line. Extend number line diagrams and coordinate axes familiar from previous grades to represent points on the line and in the plane with negative number coordinates.
Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.

content: Use ratio reasoning to convert measurement units; manipulate and transform units appropriately when multiplying or dividing quantities.
meta: Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.
Understand ratio concepts and use ratio reasoning to solve problems.

content: Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100 (e.g., 30% of a quantity means 30/100 times the quantity); solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent.
meta: Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.
Understand ratio concepts and use ratio reasoning to solve problems.

content: Solve unit rate problems including those involving unit pricing and constant speed.
meta: Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.
Understand ratio concepts and use ratio reasoning to solve problems.

content: Make tables of equivalent ratios relating quantities with whole number measurements, find missing values in the tables, and plot the pairs of values on the coordinate plane. Use tables to compare ratios.
meta: Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.
Understand ratio concepts and use ratio reasoning to solve problems.

content: Find probabilities of compound events using organized lists, tables, tree diagrams, and simulation.
meta: Investigate chance processes and develop, use, and evaluate probability models.

content: Develop a probability model and use it to find probabilities of events. Compare probabilities from a model to observed frequencies; if the agreement is not good, explain possible sources of the discrepancy.
meta: Investigate chance processes and develop, use, and evaluate probability models.

content: Approximate the probability of a chance event by collecting data on the chance process that produces it and observing its long-run relative frequency, and predict the approximate relative frequency given the probability.
meta: Investigate chance processes and develop, use, and evaluate probability models.

content: Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1 that expresses the likelihood of the event occurring. Larger numbers indicate greater likelihood. A probability near 0 indicates an unlikely event, a probability around 1/2 indicates an event that is neither unlikely nor likely, and a probability near 1 indicates a likely event.
meta: Investigate chance processes and develop, use, and evaluate probability models.

content: Use measures of center and measures of variability for numerical data from random samples to draw informal comparative inferences about two populations.
meta: Draw informal comparative inferences about two populations.

content: Informally assess the degree of visual overlap of two numerical data distributions with similar variabilities, measuring the difference between the centers by expressing it as a multiple of a measure of variability.
meta: Draw informal comparative inferences about two populations.

content: Use data from a random sample to draw inferences about a population with an unknown characteristic of interest. Generate multiple samples (or simulated samples) of the same size to gauge the variation in estimates or predictions.
meta: Use random sampling to draw inferences about a population.

content: Understand that statistics can be used to gain information about a population by examining a sample of the population; generalizations about a population from a sample are valid only if the sample is representative of that population. Understand that random sampling tends to produce representative samples and support valid inferences.
meta: Use random sampling to draw inferences about a population.

content: Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.
meta: Solve real-life and mathematical problems using numerical and algebraic expressions and equations.

content: Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any form (whole numbers, fractions, and decimals), using tools strategically. Apply properties of operations to calculate with numbers in any form; convert between forms as appropriate; and assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies.
meta: Solve real-life and mathematical problems using numerical and algebraic expressions and equations.

content: Understand that rewriting an expression in different forms in a problem context can shed light on the problem and how the quantities in it are related.
meta: Use properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions.

content: Apply properties of operations as strategies to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.
meta: Use properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions.

content: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving the four operations with rational numbers.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of operations with fractions to add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational numbers.

content: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division and of fractions to multiply and divide rational numbers.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of operations with fractions to add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational numbers.

content: Apply and extend previous understandings of addition and subtraction to add and subtract rational numbers; represent addition and subtraction on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of operations with fractions to add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational numbers.

content: Use proportional relationships to solve multistep ratio and percent problems.
meta: Analyze proportional relationships and use them to solve real-world and mathematical problems.

content: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.
meta: Analyze proportional relationships and use them to solve real-world and mathematical problems.

content: Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions, including ratios of lengths, areas and other quantities measured in like or different units.
meta: Analyze proportional relationships and use them to solve real-world and mathematical problems.

content: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, volume and surface area of two- and three-dimensional objects composed of triangles, quadrilaterals, polygons, cubes, and right prisms.
meta: Solve real-life and mathematical problems involving angle measure, area, surface area, and volume.

content: Use facts about supplementary, complementary, vertical, and adjacent angles in a multi-step problem to write and solve simple equations for an unknown angle in a figure.
meta: Solve real-life and mathematical problems involving angle measure, area, surface area, and volume.

content: Know the formulas for the area and circumference of a circle and use them to solve problems; give an informal derivation of the relationship between the circumference and area of a circle.
meta: Solve real-life and mathematical problems involving angle measure, area, surface area, and volume.

content: Describe the two-dimensional figures that result from slicing three-dimensional figures, as in plane sections of right rectangular prisms and right rectangular pyramids.
meta: Draw, construct, and describe geometrical figures and describe the relationships between them.

content: Draw (freehand, with ruler and protractor, and with technology) geometric shapes with given conditions. Focus on constructing triangles from three measures of angles or sides, noticing when the conditions determine a unique triangle, more than one triangle, or no triangle.
meta: Draw, construct, and describe geometrical figures and describe the relationships between them.

content: Solve problems involving scale drawings of geometric figures, including computing actual lengths and areas from a scale drawing and reproducing a scale drawing at a different scale.
meta: Draw, construct, and describe geometrical figures and describe the relationships between them.

content: Design and use a simulation to generate frequencies for compound events.
meta: Find probabilities of compound events using organized lists, tables, tree diagrams, and simulation.
Investigate chance processes and develop, use, and evaluate probability models.

content: Represent sample spaces for compound events using methods such as organized lists, tables and tree diagrams. For an event described in everyday language (e.g., "rolling double sixes"), identify the outcomes in the sample space which compose the event.
meta: Find probabilities of compound events using organized lists, tables, tree diagrams, and simulation.
Investigate chance processes and develop, use, and evaluate probability models.

content: Understand that, just as with simple events, the probability of a compound event is the fraction of outcomes in the sample space for which the compound event occurs.
meta: Find probabilities of compound events using organized lists, tables, tree diagrams, and simulation.
Investigate chance processes and develop, use, and evaluate probability models.

content: Develop a probability model (which may not be uniform) by observing frequencies in data generated from a chance process.
meta: Develop a probability model and use it to find probabilities of events. Compare probabilities from a model to observed frequencies; if the agreement is not good, explain possible sources of the discrepancy.
Investigate chance processes and develop, use, and evaluate probability models.

content: Develop a uniform probability model by assigning equal probability to all outcomes, and use the model to determine probabilities of events.
meta: Develop a probability model and use it to find probabilities of events. Compare probabilities from a model to observed frequencies; if the agreement is not good, explain possible sources of the discrepancy.
Investigate chance processes and develop, use, and evaluate probability models.

content: Solve word problems leading to inequalities of the form px + q > r or px + q < r, where p, q, and r are specific rational numbers. Graph the solution set of the inequality and interpret it in the context of the problem.
meta: Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.
Solve real-life and mathematical problems using numerical and algebraic expressions and equations.

content: Solve word problems leading to equations of the form px + q = r and p(x + q) = r, where p, q, and r are specific rational numbers. Solve equations of these forms fluently. Compare an algebraic solution to an arithmetic solution, identifying the sequence of the operations used in each approach.
meta: Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.
Solve real-life and mathematical problems using numerical and algebraic expressions and equations.

content: Convert a rational number to a decimal using long division; know that the decimal form of a rational number terminates in 0s or eventually repeats.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division and of fractions to multiply and divide rational numbers.
Apply and extend previous understandings of operations with fractions to add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational numbers.

content: Apply properties of operations as strategies to multiply and divide rational numbers.
meta: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division and of fractions to multiply and divide rational numbers.
Apply and extend previous understandings of operations with fractions to add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational numbers.
